apple: natural skin with colors like red, green, or yellow
aquarium_fish: Transparent boundaries (like glass) of a tank or bowl
smaller size relative to the surroundings
streamlined body without a pronounced beak
baby: the presence of a pacifier, bottle, or toys
bear: potential presence of a natural environment (e.g., forest, wilderness)
Absence of a flat, paddle-like tail
beaver: presence of a dam or lodge nearby
Presence of a dam or lodge nearby
Generally found near water or associated with dam-building activities
bed: Bedding such as sheets, blankets, and comforters
presence of room or interior decor elements
bee: presence of hair or fuzz on the body
beetle: Antennae shape (beetle antennae are often more varied in shape compared to lobsters)
generally smaller size compared to most crabs
Segmented body with three distinct parts: head, thorax, abdomen
bottle: transparent or translucent material (often glass or plastic)
label or branding on the surface
Transparent or semi-transparent material (usually glass or plastic)
bowl: Hollow inside for holding food or liquid
Often made of ceramic, glass, or metal
Made from materials like ceramic, glass, or metal
bridge: connectivity between two points over a gap (like a river or valley)
bus: steering wheel (buses have steering wheels, trains do not)
butterfly: lack of webs or webbing in the background
camel: Tail with a tuft of hair
Tail with tuft of hair at the end
Distinct facial features such as eyes, nose, and mouth
castle: Size and scale of the structure
caterpillar: Lacking fur or stripes typical of a tiger
Many legs, usually appearing as small, stubby appendages
many small legs (usually more than six)
patterns or specific markings typical of caterpillars (e.g., stripes or specific color patterns)
cattle: Absence of clothing and human facial features
chair: Height generally designed for sitting as opposed to the taller height of tables
chimpanzee: dark, coarse hair covering most of the body
clock: Absence of human features (eyes, mouth, etc.)
presence of gears or mechanical parts
Presence of a frame or casing around the face
cockroach: Presence of head, thorax, and abdomen sections
couch: a living room or lounge setting
legs or a base that is not connected to rails
crab: Absence of a long, extended tail
crocodile: a more horizontal body posture when on land
cup: Handle: Cups often have handles, while cans do not.
Design: Cups might have printed patterns, logos, or colors that differ from the uniform metallic appearance of a can.
Handle (optional but common in many cups)
dinosaur: Blowhole on top of the head
absence of modern human-made objects or environments around them
a longer neck compared to body length
dolphin: Presence of water or ocean setting
Tail fluke in a horizontal orientation
elephant: large ears (for an elephant, smaller for a mouse)
flatfish: Flattened body lying on the ocean floor
both eyes on one side of the body
Paired pectoral fins on either side of the body, near the head
forest: presence of wildlife such as birds, squirrels, or deer
natural ground cover like leaves, moss, or underbrush
Absence of human characteristics (e.g., clothing, facial features, limbs)
hamster: **Color patterns**: Hamsters can have a variety of color patterns including patches and bands, while mice often have a more uniform color.
often found in a cage or other small enclosure
house: larger size relative to human scale
keyboard: music stand or sheet music holder
Typically wired or wireless connection to a computer
lawn_mower: Operator seating: Lawn mowers typically have a single seat or a standing platform for an operator, often with handlebars. Tanks have enclosed cabins and space for multiple crew members.
Wheels with a larger diameter in the rear
Engine placement: Lawn mower engines are usually visible either at the front or rear, while tank engines are enclosed within the armored structure.
leopard: Smaller size compared to a tiger
lion: Long tail with a tuft of hair at the end
lizard: absence of feathers (many modern reconstructions of dinosaurs show feathers)
lobster: found in marine or seafood contexts
man: Typically distinct color palette for skin and clothing
Presence of accessories often worn by adults, such as a watch or glasses
maple_tree: Stems and foliage extending from the trunk
Palmate leaf shape (veins spread out from a single point)
Opposite leaf arrangement on the branches
mountain: vegetation such as trees, shrubs, or alpine plants
natural geological formations like cliffs, peaks, and valleys
mushroom: Gills or pores under the cap
Often found in natural settings like forests, soil, or decaying wood
oak_tree: isolated tree rather than a dense collection of trees
orange: small size compared to a ray
orchid: Grown in pots or natural settings
Aerial roots: Many orchids can be found with aerial roots, often extending outside the pot or clinging to trees and other surfaces.
otter: Long, tapered tail (as opposed to the flat, paddle-like tail of a beaver)
palm_tree: Lack of human features like eyes, nose, mouth, arms, and legs
Smooth or textured trunk, often with ring-like scars
pear: absence of metallic shine or reflection
skin texture (often smoother for pears, and sometimes with small brown specks)
Size that fits in the palm of a hand
Smooth, often yellow or green skin
pine_tree: Visible trunk of a solitary tree
plain: **Presence of rocks, soil, or other landforms** vs. **smooth, moist skin**
plate: May have a glossy or polished finish
Made of ceramic, porcelain, glass, or plastic
poppy: Lack of human features (e.g., eyes, nose, mouth, limbs)
Central cluster of stamens and pistils within the flower
Small size compared to the massive size of a tank
porcupine: Short limbs and small, rounded snout
possum: Head shape: Possums have a more elongated head, while mice have a more rounded head.
Fewer and less prominent teeth compared to a wolf
rabbit: generally herbivorous diet (if depicted with plants)
raccoon: Grayish to brown fur with a grizzled appearance
Distinctive black and gray fur pattern
ray: Pectoral fins that extend widely from the body
eyes located on the top of the body
road: Relatively flat and straight stretches (though roads can have curves and inclines)
rocket: Usually seen in a vertical launch position
presence of a launch pad or gantry
metallic structure and seams or rivets
large size compared to typical cans
rose: Lack of facial features, limbs, or human clothing
The color and shape of the bloom
Leaves: Roses have green, serrated leaves that grow in an alternate pattern on the stem.
seal: Pack behavior (if multiple animals are visible)
Short, flipper-like limbs (seals have shorter flippers compared to dolphins' long fins)
shark: body shape: Sharks generally have a more streamlined, torpedo-like body shape, whereas dolphins have a more elongated and slender body.
gill slits: Sharks have visible gill slits on the sides of their heads, while dolphins do not have gill slits and instead have a blowhole on top of their heads.
Gill Slits: Sharks have multiple visible gill slits on the sides of their heads, typically five to seven, whereas whales have a single blowhole or pair of blowholes on top of their heads.
skunk: presence of facial features like eyes, nose, and mouth
Presence of scent glands at the base of the tail
snail: Movement: Snails usually move slowly by gliding on their muscular foot, while crabs scuttle sideways or walk on their legs.
Slimy Trail: Snails leave a mucous trail as they move.
small size compared to a human
snake: single pair of eyes on the head
spider: Two main body segments (cephalothorax and abdomen)
Organic shape, not rigid or cylindrical
Segmented body, typically divided into two parts: cephalothorax and abdomen
squirrel: lack of distinctive rings on the tail
sunflower: Green leaves arranged around the stem
sweet_pepper: No human features like eyes, nose, mouth, or hair
Bright colors like red, green, yellow, or orange
Absence of large bodies of water or mountains
No petals or complex floral structure
table: made of materials like wood, metal, or glass
Often accompanied by chairs or seating around it
absence of timekeeping elements (e.g., hands, numbers, clock face)
Variety of shapes, such as rectangular, round, or square
telephone: Lack of a display screen showing images or videos
Handset with a receiver and mouthpiece
dial pad or touch screen with numeric keys
television: Wall mount brackets or stand legs
train: Overhead lines or pantographs: Trains might have overhead electrical wires or pantographs, buses do not.
trout: absence of large, prominent dorsal fin as seen in sharks
tulip: Stem: Tulips have sturdy, straight stems, whereas poppies often have slender, wiry stems.
Lack of facial features and limbs
turtle: typically muted colors like brown, green, or gray
four legs with webbed or clawed feet
Ability to retract head and limbs into shell
wardrobe: Stationary and does not move on its own
Placement against a wall or as part of furniture setup
decorative elements like carvings or mirrors
whale: dorsal fin (if present) located on the back
wolf: Fur coat covering the entire body
woman: Contextual clues (e.g., presence in an adult workspace or environment)
worm: no discernible facial features like eyes or snout
